content.title: If you have concerns about your child’s:
content.concern_1: Receptive Language (understanding language – e.g., words and concepts, following directions, answering questions)

content.concern_4: Limited use of sounds, words or sentences

faq.title: FAQ
faq.subtitle: Look Here
faq.description: Find answers to the most common questions about speech therapy services and how we can help your child.

question1.question: What is speech therapy?
question1.answer: Speech therapy helps improve communication skills like speaking, understanding, fluency, and voice. It's useful for articulation issues, stuttering, or developmental disorders.

question2.question: Who does a speech therapist work with?
question2.answer: We work with children (speech delays, autism), adults (post-stroke, Parkinson's), and individuals with specific disorders like stuttering or dysphonia.

question3.question: How do I know if my child needs speech therapy?
question3.answer: Common signs include: not babbling by 12 months, trouble pronouncing words or following instructions, and delays compared to peers. Early evaluation is key.

question4.question: How long does treatment last?
question4.answer: It depends on the case. Some improve in weeks, others need months or years. Progress varies based on age, severity, and session frequency.

question5.question: What happens during a session?
question5.answer: Sessions include an initial assessment, interactive activities (games, exercises), personalized techniques, and homework tasks. Sessions are practical and fun, especially for kids.

question6.question: Is speech therapy covered by insurance?
question6.answer: It depends on your insurance and medical condition. Some cover part of the costs, especially for diagnosed medical issues. Check with your provider for details.
